summary: The Benelux Economic Union, often referred to simply as "Benelux," represents a unified legal framework among Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg, aimed at liberalized economic cooperation. This framework facilitates the resolution of disputes through courts that hear cases involving defendants domiciled in any of the member states. By stipulating predictable regulations, the Union absorbs various legal principles, ensuring that outstanding judgments are enforced across borders. Unlike other regional agreements, Benelux allows for the free movement of goods, thereby preventing irreconcilable conflicts in patent infringement cases. This cooperative model serves as a subsidiary to broader EU regulations, enhancing the legal predictability necessary for economic integration.
